Overlay-based Decentralized Federated Learning in Bandwidth-limited Networks

Yudi Huang Pennsylvania State UniversityState College, PAUSA yxh5389@psu.edu ,Â  Tingyang Sun Pennsylvania State UniversityState College, PAUSA tfs5679@psu.edu Â andÂ  Ting He Pennsylvania State UniversityState College, PAUSA tinghe@psu.edu
(2024)
Abstract.

The emerging machine learning paradigm of decentralized federated learning (DFL) has the promise of greatly boosting the deployment of artificial intelligence (AI) by directly learning across distributed agents without centralized coordination. Despite significant efforts on improving the communication efficiency of DFL, most existing solutions were based on the simplistic assumption that neighboring agents are physically adjacent in the underlying communication network, which fails to correctly capture the communication cost when learning over a general bandwidth-limited network, as encountered in many edge networks. In this work, we address this gap by leveraging recent advances in network tomography to jointly design the communication demands and the communication schedule for overlay-based DFL in bandwidth-limited networks without requiring explicit cooperation from the underlying network. By carefully analyzing the structure of our problem, we decompose it into a series of optimization problems that can each be solved efficiently, to collectively minimize the total training time. Extensive data-driven simulations show that our solution can significantly accelerate DFL in comparison with state-of-the-art designs.

Decentralized federated learning, network tomography, overlay routing, mixing matrix design.

1. Introduction

As a new machine learning paradigm, federated learning (FL) allows multiple learning agents to collaboratively learn a shared model from the union of their local data without directly sharing the data (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). To achieve this goal, the agents repeatedly exchange model updates, through a centralized parameter serverÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), a hierarchy of parameter serversÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2023), or peer-to-peer links between neighboring agentsÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021), which are then aggregated to update the shared model. Due to its promise in protecting data privacy, FL has found many applications such as improving browsers (FLo, [n.â€‰d.]; Bra, [n.â€‰d.]). In particular, decentralized federated learning (DFL)Â (Lian etÂ al., 2017) has attracted significant attention. Instead of forming a star (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) or hierarchical topology (Liu etÂ al., 2023), agents in DFL can communicate along arbitrary topology, where parameter exchanges only occur between neighbors. Compared to centralized FL, DFL can avoid a single point of failure and reduce the communication complexity at the busiest node without increasing the computational complexityÂ (Lian etÂ al., 2017).

Meanwhile, FL including DFL faces significant performance challenges due to the extensive data transfer. Although the training data stay local, the agents still need to communicate frequently to exchange local model updates, which often incurs a nontrivial communication cost due to the large model size. Such communication cost can dominate the total cost of the learning task, e.g., accounting for up to 90%percent9090\% of time in cloud-based FLÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2020), and the problem is exacerbated in other networks that are more bandwidth-limited (e.g., wireless mesh networksÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2022b)). This issue has attracted tremendous interests in reducing the communication cost, including compression-based methods for reducing the amount of data per communication such as (Koloskova etÂ al., 2020a) and methods for reducing the number of communications through hyperparameter optimization such as (Wang etÂ al., 2019, 2022b; Chiu etÂ al., 2023) or adaptive communications such as (Singh etÂ al., 2022).

However, most existing works made the simplistic assumption that each pair of logically adjacent agents are also physically adjacent in the underlying communication network. This is not true in overlay-based DFL, where the connections between logically adjacent agents (i.e., overlay links) can map to arbitrary routing paths in the underlying communication network that may share links (i.e., underlay links). For example, a set of learning agents {A,B,C,D}ğ´ğµğ¶ğ·\{A,B,C,D\} may have the physical connectivity in Fig.Â 1a and the logical connectivity in Fig.Â 1b. Although connections (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B) and (C,D)ğ¶ğ·(C,D) appear disjoint in the overlay, they actually map to paths sharing link (h1,h2)subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2(h_{1},h_{2}) in the underlay. Ignoring such link sharing can cause incorrect prediction of the communication time, because concurrent communications over connections with shared links can take longer than stand-alone communication on each of them, and the problem can be exacerbated by heterogeneous capacities and background loads at underlay links. Most existing works ignored such complications by assuming the communication time to be proportional to the maximum number of neighbors an agent communicates with (Wang etÂ al., 2022b; Chiu etÂ al., 2023; Hua etÂ al., 2022; LeÂ Bars etÂ al., 2023), which generally leads to suboptimal designs in the case of overlay-based DFL.

We want to address this gap without requiring explicit cooperation from the underlay network, i.e., the agents can neither directly observe the internal state of the underlay (e.g., routing topology, link capacities) nor control its internal behavior. Such scenarios arise naturally when the agents are interconnected by a public network. In particular, we are interested in running DFL over bandwidth-limited networks, which models many application scenarios such as HetNets (Chen etÂ al., 2022b), device-to-device networks (Xing etÂ al., 2021), IoT networksÂ (Pinyoanuntapong etÂ al., 2022), underwater networks (Pei etÂ al., 2023), and power line communication networks (Jia etÂ al., 2022). In contrast to high-bandwidth networks such as inter-datacenter networks (Marfoq etÂ al., 2020), bandwidth-limited networks are more sensitive to communication demands generated by DFL and are thus in greater needs of proper designs. To this end, we propose an optimization framework for overlay-based DFL that jointly designs the communication demands and the communication schedule within the overlay, without explicit cooperation from the underlay. Building upon recent advances in network tomographyÂ (Huang and He, 2023) and mixing matrix designÂ (Chiu etÂ al., 2023), we cast the problem into a set of tractable optimizations that collectively minimize the total time in achieving a given level of convergence.

1.1. Related Work

Decentralized federated learning. Initially proposed under a centralized architecture (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), FL was later extended to a fully decentralized architectureÂ (Lian etÂ al., 2017), which was shown to achieve the same computational complexity but a lower communication complexity. Since then a number of improvements have been developed, e.g., (Tang etÂ al., 2018b; Lu and Sa, 2021), but these works only focused on reducing the number of iterations.

Communication cost reduction. There are two general approaches for reducing the communication cost in FL: reducing the amount of data per communication through compression, e.g., (Koloskova etÂ al., 2020a; Lu and DeÂ Sa, 2020; Tang etÂ al., 2018a), and reducing the number of communications, e.g., (Wang and Joshi, 2019; Tran etÂ al., 2019; Wang etÂ al., 2019). The two approaches can be combined for further improvement (Singh etÂ al., 2022, 2021). Instead of either activating all the links or activating none, it has been recognized that better efficiency can be achieved by activating subsets of links. To this end, (Singh etÂ al., 2022, 2021) proposed an event-triggered mechanism and (Wang etÂ al., 2022b; Chiu etÂ al., 2023) proposed to activate links with predetermined probabilities. In this regard, our work designs predetermined link activation as in (Wang etÂ al., 2022b; Chiu etÂ al., 2023), which provides more predictable performance than event-triggered mechanisms, but we consider a cost model tailored to overlay-based DFL: instead of measuring the communication time by the number of matchings (Wang etÂ al., 2022b; Chiu etÂ al., 2023) or the maximum degree (Hua etÂ al., 2022; LeÂ Bars etÂ al., 2023), we evaluate the minimum time to complete all the activated agent-to-agent communications over a bandwidth-limited underlay, while taking into account heterogeneous capacities and possibly shared links.

Topology design in DFL. The logical topology defining the neighborhoods of learning agents is an important design parameter in DFL that controls the communication demands during training. The impact of this topology on the convergence rate of DFL has been mostly captured through the spectral gap of the mixing matrixÂ (Lian etÂ al., 2017; NediÄ‡ etÂ al., 2018; Neglia etÂ al., 2019, 2020; Jiang etÂ al., 2023) or equivalent parametersÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2022b). Although recent works have identified other parameters that can impact the convergence rate, such as the effective number of neighborsÂ (Vogels etÂ al., 2022) and the neighborhood heterogeneityÂ (LeÂ Bars etÂ al., 2023), these results just pointed out additional factors and did not invalidate the impact of spectral gap. Based on the identified convergence parameters, several solutions have been proposed to design the logical topology to balance the convergence rate and the cost per communication roundÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2022b; Chiu etÂ al., 2023; LeÂ Bars etÂ al., 2023), and some solutions combined topology design with other optimizations (e.g., bandwidth allocationÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2022a), model pruningÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2023)) for further improvement. In this regard, our work also includes topology design based on a parameter related to the spectral gap, but we explicitly consider the communication schedule to serve the demands triggered by the designed topology over a bandwidth-limited underlay to optimize the overall wall-clock time of overlay-based DFL. To our knowledge, the only existing work addressing overlay-based DFL is (Marfoq etÂ al., 2020). However, it assumed a special underlay where the paths connecting learning agents only share links at the first and the last hops, whose capacities are assumed to be known. While this model may suit high-bandwidth underlays such as inter-datacenter networks, it fails to capture the communication cost in bandwidth-limited underlays as addressed in our work.

Network-aware distributed computing. It was known that awareness to the state of the communication underlay is important for data-intensive distributed computing tasksÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2020). Several works attempted to solve this problem in the context of cloud networks, assuming either a black-box network (Luo etÂ al., 2020; Gong etÂ al., 2015; LaCurts etÂ al., 2013) or a white-box network (Chen etÂ al., 2022a). In this regard, our work assumes a black-box underlay as in (Luo etÂ al., 2020; Gong etÂ al., 2015; LaCurts etÂ al., 2013), but unlike the simple heuristics used in these works, we leverage state-of-the-art techniques from network tomographyÂ (He etÂ al., 2021) to estimate the necessary parameters about the underlay. Notably, we recently discovered in (Huang and He, 2023) that network tomography can consistently estimate coarse parameters about the underlay that allows the overlay to compute the capacity region for communications between the overlay nodes, which we will use to design the communication schedule for overlay-based DFL.

1.2. Summary of Contributions

We jointly design the communication demands and the communication schedule for overlay-based DFL in a bandwidth-limited uncooperative underlay, with the following contributions:

  1. (1)

    We consider, for the first time, communication optimization in DFL on top of a bandwidth-limited underlay network with arbitrary topology. To this end, we propose a general framework for jointly designing the communication demands and the communication schedule (e.g., routing, rates) among the learning agents, without cooperation from the underlay.

  2. (2)

    We tackle the complexity challenge by decomposing the overall problem into a series of smaller subproblems, that are collectively designed to minimize the total training time to achieve a given level of convergence. Through carefully designed relaxations, we convert each subproblem into a tractable optimization to develop efficient solutions.

  3. (3)

    We evaluate the proposed solution in comparison with benchmarks based on real network topologies and datasets. Our results show that (i) our design of the communication demands can already reduce the training time substantially without compromising the quality of the trained model, (ii) our design of the communication schedule further increases the improvement, and (iii) the observations remain valid under realistic inference errors about the underlay.

Roadmap. SectionÂ 2 describes our overall problem, SectionÂ 3 presents our solution and analysis, SectionÂ 4 presents our performance evaluation, and SectionÂ 5 concludes the paper. All the proofs can be found in AppendixÂ A.

2.4. Design Objective

Our goal is to jointly design the communication demands between the agents and the communication schedule about how to service these demands so as to minimize the total (wall-clock) time for the learning task to reach a given level of convergence. The challenges are two-fold: (i) the design of communication demands faces the tradeoff between communicating more per iteration and converging in fewer iterations versus communicating less per iteration and converging in more iterations, and (ii) the design of communication schedule faces the lack of observability and controllability within the underlay network. Below, we will tackle these challenges by combining techniques from network tomography and mixing matrix design.

3. Proposed Solution

Our approach is to first characterize the total training time as an explicit function of the set of activated links in the overlay, and then optimize this set. We will focus on a deterministic design that can give a predictable training time, and thus the iteration index kğ‘˜k will be omitted. For ease of presentation, we will consider the set of activated overlay links, denoted by EaâŠ†E~subscriptğ¸ğ‘~ğ¸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}, as undirected links, as the pair of links between two agents must be activated at the same time.

3.1. Communication Schedule Optimization

Given a set of overlay links EaâŠ†E~subscriptğ¸ğ‘~ğ¸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E} activated in an iteration, each (i,j)âˆˆEağ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¸ğ‘(i,j)\in E_{a} triggers two communications, one for agent iğ‘–i to send its parameter vector to agent jğ‘—j and the other for agent jğ‘—j to send its parameter vector to agent iğ‘–i. However, directly sending the parameter vectors along the underlay routing paths can lead to suboptimal performance. For example, consider Fig.Â 2. If Ea={(A,B),(A,D)}subscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ´ğµğ´ğ·E_{a}=\{(A,B),(A,D)\} but both pÂ¯A,BsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ´ğµ\underline{p}_{A,B} and pÂ¯A,DsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ´ğ·\underline{p}_{A,D} traverse the same underlay link (h1,h2)subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2(h_{1},h_{2}), directly communicating between the activated agent pairs can take longer than redirecting part of the traffic through other agents (e.g., redirecting Aâ†’Dâ†’ğ´ğ·A\to D traffic through the overlay path Aâ†’Câ†’Dâ†’ğ´ğ¶â†’ğ·A\to C\to D). The same holds if the capacity of the direct path is low, but the capacity through other agents is higher (e.g., if (h2,D)subscriptâ„2ğ·(h_{2},D) is a slow link, then redirecting Aâ†’Dâ†’ğ´ğ·A\to D traffic through Cğ¶C can bypass it to achieve a higher rate). This observation motivates the need of optimizing how to serve the demands triggered by the activated links by routing within the overlay.

3.1.1. Demand Model

Let Îºisubscriptğœ…ğ‘–\kappa_{i} denote the size of the parameter vector (or its compressed version if model compression is used) at agent iğ‘–i. A straightforward way to model the communication demands triggered by a set of activated links Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} is to generate two unicast flows for each activated link (i,j)âˆˆEağ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¸ğ‘(i,j)\in E_{a}, one in each direction. However, this model will lead to a suboptimal communication schedule as it ignores the fact that some flows carry identical content. Specifically, all flows originating from the same agent will carry the latest parameter vector at this agent. Thus, the actual communication demands is a set of multicast flows, each for distributing the parameter vector of an activated agent (incident to at least one activated link) to the agents it needs to share parameters with. 3.1.3. Important Special Case

In the practical application scenario where the underlay is an edge network spanning a relatively small area, the propagation delay li,jsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘—l_{i,j} will be negligible compared to the data transfer time. Moreover, since all the agents are training the same model, the sizes of the local parameter vectors will be identical without compression, i.e., Îºiâ‰¡Îºsubscriptğœ…ğ‘–ğœ…\kappa_{i}\equiv\kappa (âˆ€iâˆˆVfor-allğ‘–ğ‘‰\forall i\in V). Even if compression is used, since the compressed model sizes will vary dynamically across iterations, tailoring the communication schedule to the compressed model sizes will require re-solving (5) for every iteration, which is expensive in terms of both the overhead in collecting all the compressed model sizes and the computation cost. It is thus more practical to optimize the communication schedule only once at the beginning of the learning task and use it throughout the task, and setting Îºiâ‰¡Îºsubscriptğœ…ğ‘–ğœ…\kappa_{i}\equiv\kappa (the uncompressed model size) in solving (5) will provide a guaranteed per-iteration time, even though compression can be applied during training to further reduce the time. In this scenario, the completion time for a given multicast flow hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in H is reduced to Îº/dhğœ…subscriptğ‘‘â„\kappa/d_{h}, and the overall completion time of an iteration is reduced to Îº/(minhâˆˆHâ¡dh)ğœ…subscriptâ„ğ»subscriptğ‘‘â„\kappa/(\min_{h\in H}d_{h}). 3.1.4. Handling Uncooperative Underlay

When learning over an uncooperative underlay as considered in this work, the overlay cannot directly solve (5), because the capacity constraint (5c) requires the knowledge of the routing in the underlay and the capacities of the underlay links. In absence of such knowledge, we leverage a recent result from (Huang and He, 2023) to convert this constraint into an equivalent form that can be consistently estimated by the overlay. To this end, we introduce the following notion from (Huang and He, 2023), adapted to our problem setting.

Definition 0 ((Huang and He, 2023)).

A category of underlay links Î“FsubscriptÎ“ğ¹\Gamma_{F} for a set of overlay links Fğ¹F (FâŠ†Eğ¹ğ¸F\subseteq E) is the set of underlay links traversed by and only by the underlay routing paths for the overlay links in Fğ¹F out of all the paths for Eğ¸E, i.e,555Here pÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{p} is interpreted as the set of underlay links traversed by path pÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{p}.

(8) Î“Fâ‰”(â‹‚(i,j)âˆˆFpÂ¯i,j)âˆ–(â‹ƒ(i,j)âˆˆEâˆ–FpÂ¯i,j).â‰”subscriptÎ“ğ¹subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¹subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¸ğ¹subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\Gamma_{F}\coloneqq\Big{(}\bigcap_{(i,j)\in{F}}\underline{p}_{i,j}\Big{)}\setminus\Big{(}\bigcup_{(i,j)\in E\setminus F}\underline{p}_{i,j}\Big{)}.

The key observation is that since all the underlay links in the same category are traversed by the same set of overlay links, they must carry the same traffic load from the overlay. Therefore, we can reduce the per-link capacity constraint (5c) into the following per-category capacity constraint:

(9) âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆFâˆ‘hâˆˆHfiâ€‹jhâ‰¤CF,âˆ€FâŠ†Eâ€‹Â withÂ â€‹Î“Fâ‰ âˆ…,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¹subscriptâ„ğ»subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â„ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¶ğ¹for-allğ¹ğ¸Â withÂ subscriptÎ“ğ¹\displaystyle\sum_{(i,j)\in{F}}\sum_{h\in H}f^{h}_{ij}\leq C_{F},~{}~{}~{}\forall F\subseteq E\mbox{ with }\Gamma_{F}\neq\emptyset,

where CFâ‰”mineÂ¯âˆˆÎ“Fâ¡CeÂ¯â‰”subscriptğ¶ğ¹subscriptÂ¯ğ‘’subscriptÎ“ğ¹subscriptğ¶Â¯ğ‘’C_{F}\coloneqq\min_{\underline{e}\in\Gamma_{F}}C_{\underline{e}}, referred to as the category capacity, is the minimum capacity of all the links in category Î“FsubscriptÎ“ğ¹\Gamma_{F}. The new constraint (9) is equivalent to the original constraint (5c), as an overlay communication schedule satisfies one of these constraints if and only if it satisfies the other. However, instead of requiring detailed internal information about the underlay (i.e., (pÂ¯i,j)(i,j)âˆˆEsubscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¸(\underline{p}_{i,j})_{(i,j)\in E} and (CeÂ¯)eÂ¯âˆˆEÂ¯subscriptsubscriptğ¶Â¯ğ‘’Â¯ğ‘’Â¯ğ¸(C_{\underline{e}})_{\underline{e}\in\underline{E}}), constraint (9) only requires the knowledge of the nonempty categories and the corresponding category capacities.

In the special case of li,j=0subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘—0l_{i,j}=0 âˆ€(i,j)âˆˆEfor-allğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¸\forall(i,j)\in E and Îºhâ‰¡Îºsubscriptğœ…â„ğœ…\kappa_{h}\equiv\kappa âˆ€hâˆˆHfor-allâ„ğ»\forall h\in H, we have a category-based counterpart of LemmaÂ 3.1 as follows.

Under the assumption that every underlay link introduces a nontrivial performance impact (e.g., non-zero loss/queueing probability), (Huang and He, 2023) provided an algorithm that can consistently infer the nonempty categories from losses/delays of packets sent concurrently through the overlay links, under the assumption that concurrently sent packets will experience the same performance when traversing a shared underlay link. Moreover, by leveraging state-of-the-art single-path residual capacity estimation methods, (Huang and He, 2023) gave a simple algorithm that can accurately estimate the effective category capacity C~Fsubscript~ğ¶ğ¹\widetilde{C}_{F} for each detected nonempty category, that can be used in place of CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} in (9) without changing the feasible region. (12) âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆFâˆ‘hâˆˆHfiâ€‹jhâ‰¤C^F,âˆ€Fâˆˆâ„±^,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¹subscriptâ„ğ»subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â„ğ‘–ğ‘—subscript^ğ¶ğ¹for-allğ¹^â„±\displaystyle\sum_{(i,j)\in{F}}\sum_{h\in H}f^{h}_{ij}\leq\widehat{C}_{F},~{}~{}~{}\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},

which can then be used in place of (5c) in (5) to compute an optimized overlay communication schedule. In the special case considered in LemmaÂ 3.3, we can estimate the minimum completion time under a given routing solution by

(13) Ï„^:=ÎºminFâˆˆâ„±^â¡C^F/tF.assign^ğœğœ…subscriptğ¹^â„±subscript^ğ¶ğ¹subscriptğ‘¡ğ¹\displaystyle\widehat{\tau}:={\kappa\over\min_{F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}}}\widehat{C}_{F}/t_{F}}.

Remark: First, the traversal of overlay paths through the overlay links is directional, and the traversal of underlay routing paths through the underlay links is also directional. Correspondingly, the overlay links in a category index Fğ¹F should be treated as directed links (i.e., (i,j)âˆˆFğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¹(i,j)\in F only implies that the underlay links in Î“FsubscriptÎ“ğ¹\Gamma_{F} are traversed by the path pÂ¯i,jsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\underline{p}_{i,j}). This is not to be confused with treating the activated links in Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} as undirected links, because each (i,j)âˆˆEağ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¸ğ‘(i,j)\in E_{a} stands for a parameter exchange between agents iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j. Moreover, we only use the activated links Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} to determine the flow demands Hğ»H, but any overlay link in Eğ¸E can be used in serving these flows.

3.1.5. Additional Optimization Opportunities and Challenges

The formulation (5) treats each overlay node that is neither the source nor one of the destinations of a multicast flow as a pure relay, but this node is actually a learning agent capable of aggregating the parameter vectors. This observation raises two questions: (i) Can an agent include parameter vectors relayed through it in its own parameter aggregation? (ii) If an agent relays multiple parameter vectors for different sources, can it forward the aggregated vector instead of the individual vectors?

To answer the first question, consider the case in Fig.Â 2 when Ağ´A sends its parameter vector ğ’™Asubscriptğ’™ğ´\bm{x}_{A} to Dğ·D through the overlay path Aâ†’Câ†’Dâ†’ğ´ğ¶â†’ğ·A\to C\to D. If Cğ¶C includes ğ’™Asubscriptğ’™ğ´\bm{x}_{A} in its own parameter aggregation with a non-zero weight WCâ€‹Asubscriptğ‘Šğ¶ğ´W_{CA}, then by the symmetry of the mixing matrix, Ağ´A must also include ğ’™Csubscriptğ’™ğ¶\bm{x}_{C} in its parameter aggregation with weight WAâ€‹C=WCâ€‹Asubscriptğ‘Šğ´ğ¶subscriptğ‘Šğ¶ğ´W_{AC}=W_{CA}, which is equivalent to activating the overlay link (A,C)ğ´ğ¶(A,C). As we have left the optimization of the activated links Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} to another subproblem (SectionÂ 3.3), there is no need to include relayed parameter vectors in parameter aggregation when optimizing the communication schedule for a given set of activated links.

To answer the second question, consider the case in Fig.Â 3 when the overlay routes the multicast from Ağ´A to {D,E}ğ·ğ¸\{D,E\} (for disseminating ğ’™Asubscriptğ’™ğ´\bm{x}_{A}) over Aâ†’Câ†’Dâ†’Eâ†’ğ´ğ¶â†’ğ·â†’ğ¸A\to C\to D\to E, and the multicast from BğµB to {D,E}ğ·ğ¸\{D,E\} (for disseminating ğ’™Bsubscriptğ’™ğµ\bm{x}_{B}) over Bâ†’Câ†’Dâ†’Eâ†’ğµğ¶â†’ğ·â†’ğ¸B\to C\to D\to E. Although instead of separately forwarding ğ’™Asubscriptğ’™ğ´\bm{x}_{A} and ğ’™Bsubscriptğ’™ğµ\bm{x}_{B}, Cğ¶C could aggregate them before forwarding, the aggregation will not save bandwidth for Cğ¶C, as Dğ·D needs WDâ€‹Aâ€‹ğ’™A+WDâ€‹Bâ€‹ğ’™Bsubscriptğ‘Šğ·ğ´subscriptğ’™ğ´subscriptğ‘Šğ·ğµsubscriptğ’™ğµW_{DA}\bm{x}_{A}+W_{DB}\bm{x}_{B} but Eğ¸E needs WEâ€‹Aâ€‹ğ’™A+WEâ€‹Bâ€‹ğ’™Bsubscriptğ‘Šğ¸ğ´subscriptğ’™ğ´subscriptğ‘Šğ¸ğµsubscriptğ’™ğµW_{EA}\bm{x}_{A}+W_{EB}\bm{x}_{B}, which are generally not the same. Another issue with in-network aggregation (within the overlay) is the synchronization delay introduced at the point of aggregation, and thus in-network aggregation may not reduce the completion time even when it can save bandwidth, e.g., at Dğ·D. We thus choose not to consider in-network aggregation in our formulation (5). Further optimizations exploiting such capabilities are left to future work.

3.2. Link Weight Optimization

Given the set of activated links EaâŠ†E~subscriptğ¸ğ‘~ğ¸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}, the communication time per iteration has been determined as explained in SectionÂ 3.1, but the number of iterations has not, and is heavily affected by the weights of the activated links. This leads to the question of how to minimize the number of iterations for achieving a desired level of convergence, under the constraint that only the activated links can have non-zero weights.

To answer this question, we leverage a state-of-the-art convergence bound for D-PSGD under the following assumptions:

3.3. Link Activation Optimization

Given how to optimize the communication schedule and the link weights for a given set Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} of activated links as in SectionsÂ 3.1â€“3.2, what remains is to optimize Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} itself, which is also known as â€œtopology designâ€ (Marfoq etÂ al., 2020) as (V,Ea)ğ‘‰subscriptğ¸ğ‘(V,E_{a}) depicts a subgraph of the base topology (of the overlay) that is used to determine which agents will exchange parameter vectors during DFL. The set Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} affects both the communication demands (and hence the time per iteration) and the sparsity pattern of the mixing matrix (and hence the number of iterations required). As mentioned in SectionÂ 2.4, our goal is to minimize the total training time. For learning over bandwidth-limited networks, the training time is dominated by the communication timeÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2020). We thus model the total training time by

(19) Ï„â€‹(Ea)â‹…Kâ€‹(Ea),â‹…ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘\displaystyle\tau(E_{a})\cdot K(E_{a}),

where we have used Ï„â€‹(Ea)ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘\tau(E_{a}) to denote the communication time per iteration according to (5) (with (5c) replaced by (12)), and Kâ€‹(Ea):=Kâ€‹(1âˆ’Ïâˆ—2,1)assignğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ¾1superscriptsuperscriptğœŒ21K(E_{a}):=K(1-\mathop{\rho^{*}}^{2},1) to denote the number of iterations to achieve a given level of convergence. Our goal is to minimize (19) over all the candidate values of EaâŠ†E~subscriptğ¸ğ‘~ğ¸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}.

Directly solving this optimization is intractable because its solution space is exponentially large and its objective function (19) is not given explicitly. Our approach to address this challenge is to: (i) relax Ï„â€‹(Ea)ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘\tau(E_{a}) and Kâ€‹(Ea)ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘K(E_{a}) into upper bounds that are explicit functions of Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a}, (ii) decompose the optimization to separate the impacts of Ï„â€‹(Ea)ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘\tau(E_{a}) and Kâ€‹(Ea)ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘K(E_{a}), and (iii) develop efficient solutions by identifying linkages to known problems.

(23) K(Ea):=K(1âˆ’Ïâˆ—2,1)â‰¤K(1âˆ’ÏÂ¯2,1)=:KÂ¯(Ea).\displaystyle K(E_{a}):=K\left(1-{\rho^{*}}^{2},1\right)\leq K\left(1-\overline{\rho}^{2},1\right)=:\overline{K}(E_{a}).

3.3.2. Bi-level Decomposition

Relaxing (19) into its upper bound Ï„Â¯â€‹(Ea)â‹…KÂ¯â€‹(Ea)â‹…Â¯ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘Â¯ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\cdot\overline{K}(E_{a}) provides an objective function that can be easily evaluated for any candidate Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a}. However, we still face the exponentially large solution space of EaâŠ†E~subscriptğ¸ğ‘~ğ¸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}. To address this complexity challenge, we decompose the relaxed optimization into a bi-level optimization as follows.

Lemma 3.6.

Let Î²ğ›½\beta be the maximum time per iteration. Then

(24) minEaâŠ†E~â¡Ï„Â¯â€‹(Ea)â‹…KÂ¯â€‹(Ea)=minÎ²â‰¥0â¡Î²â‹…(minÏ„Â¯â€‹(Ea)â‰¤Î²â¡KÂ¯â€‹(Ea)),â‹…subscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘~ğ¸Â¯ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘Â¯ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘â‹…subscriptğ›½0ğ›½subscriptÂ¯ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ›½Â¯ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘\displaystyle\min_{E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}}\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\cdot\overline{K}(E_{a})=\min_{\beta\geq 0}\beta\cdot\left(\min_{\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\leq\beta}\overline{K}(E_{a})\right),

and the optimal solution Eaâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a}^{*} to the RHS of (24) is also optimal for the LHS of (24).

The bi-level decomposition in (24) allows us to focus on the lower-level optimization

(25) minÏ„Â¯â€‹(Ea)â‰¤Î²â¡KÂ¯â€‹(Ea),subscriptÂ¯ğœsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ›½Â¯ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘\displaystyle\min_{\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\leq\beta}\overline{K}(E_{a}),

as the upper-level optimization only has a scalar variable Î²ğ›½\beta that can be optimized numerically once we have an efficient solution to (25).

3.3.3. Algorithms

To solve (25), we encode Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} by binary variables ğ’š:=(yiâ€‹j)(i,j)âˆˆE~assignğ’šsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸\bm{y}:=(y_{ij})_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}, where yiâ€‹j=1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—1y_{ij}=1 if (i,j)âˆˆEağ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¸ğ‘(i,j)\in E_{a} and 00 otherwise. By (20), ğ’šğ’š\bm{y} is feasible for (25) if and only if âˆ€Fâˆˆâ„±^for-allğ¹^â„±\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},

(26) âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆE~yiâ€‹jâ€‹(ÎºiÎ²âˆ’li,jâ€‹ğŸ™(i,j)âˆˆF+ÎºjÎ²âˆ’lj,iâ€‹ğŸ™(j,i)âˆˆF)â‰¤C^F,subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ…ğ‘–ğ›½subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘—subscript1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¹subscriptğœ…ğ‘—ğ›½subscriptğ‘™ğ‘—ğ‘–subscript1ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ¹subscript^ğ¶ğ¹\displaystyle\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\left({\kappa_{i}\over\beta-l_{i,j}}\mathbbm{1}_{(i,j)\in F}+{\kappa_{j}\over\beta-l_{j,i}}\mathbbm{1}_{(j,i)\in F}\right)\leq\widehat{C}_{F},

where ğŸ™â‹…subscript1â‹…\mathbbm{1}_{\cdot} denotes the indicator function.

Exact solution: We can directly try to solve the lower-level optimization (25) as a convex programming problem with integer variables. Due to the monotone relationship between KÂ¯â€‹(Ea)Â¯ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘\overline{K}(E_{a}) and ÏÂ¯Â¯ğœŒ\overline{\rho}, we can equivalently minimize ÏÂ¯Â¯ğœŒ\overline{\rho} as defined in (21) by solving

(27a) minğ’šsubscriptğ’š\displaystyle\min_{\bm{y}} ÏğœŒ\displaystyle\quad\rho
(27b) s.t. âˆ’Ïâ€‹ğ‘°âª¯ğ‘°âˆ’âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆE~yiâ€‹jâ€‹ğ‘³iâ€‹jâˆ’ğ‘±âª¯Ïâ€‹ğ‘°,precedes-or-equalsğœŒğ‘°ğ‘°subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘³ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘±precedes-or-equalsğœŒğ‘°\displaystyle-\rho\bm{I}\preceq\bm{I}-\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\bm{L}_{ij}-\bm{J}\preceq\rho\bm{I},
(27c) (â€‹26â€‹),âˆ€Fâˆˆâ„±^,italic-(26italic-)for-allğ¹^â„±\displaystyle\eqref{eq:independence constraint},~{}~{}\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},
(27d) yiâ€‹jâˆˆ{0,1},âˆ€(i,j)âˆˆE~,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—01for-allğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸\displaystyle y_{ij}\in\{0,1\},~{}~{}\forall(i,j)\in\widetilde{E},

where ğ‘³iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘³ğ‘–ğ‘—\bm{L}_{ij} is the Laplacian matrix representation of link (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) with weight Î±iâ€‹j(0)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}, i.e., entries (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) and (j,i)ğ‘—ğ‘–(j,i) are âˆ’Î±iâ€‹j(0)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—-\alpha^{(0)}_{ij} and entries (i,i)ğ‘–ğ‘–(i,i) and (j,j)ğ‘—ğ‘—(j,j) are Î±iâ€‹j(0)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha^{(0)}_{ij} (rest are zero), and (27b) ensures that the auxiliary variable Ï=ÏÂ¯ğœŒÂ¯ğœŒ\rho=\overline{\rho} as in (21) under the optimal solution.

The optimization (27) is an integer convex programming (ICP) problem, and thus in theory can be solved by ICP solvers such as (Lubin, 2017). In practice, however, ICP solvers can be slow due to their super-polynomial complexity, and in contrast to the communication schedule optimization (5) that only needs to be solved once, (27) has to be solved many times to optimize the variable Î²ğ›½\beta in the upper-level optimization. Thus, we need more efficient algorithms.

Efficient heuristics: To improve the computational efficiency, we have explored two approaches: (i) developing heuristics for (27), and (ii) further simplifying the objective function.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Heuristics for (27): Once we relax the integer constraint (27d) into yiâ€‹jâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—01y_{ij}\in[0,1], (27) becomes an SDP that can be solved in polynomial time (Jiang etÂ al., 2020). We can thus round the fractional solution into a feasible solution. However, we observe that simple rounding schemes such as greedily activating links with the largest fractional yğ‘¦y-values do not yield a good solution (see results for â€˜Relaxation-ÏğœŒ\rhoâ€™ in SectionÂ 4). Thus, we propose an iterative rounding algorithm based on successive convex approximation (SCA) as in AlgorithmÂ 1. The algorithm gradually rounds the yğ‘¦y-values for a subset of links Essubscriptğ¸ğ‘ E_{s} to 111 and those for another subset of links Eosubscriptğ¸ğ‘œE_{o} to 00 to satisfy feasibility. In each iteration, it solves the SDP relaxation of (27) with rounding constraints according to the previously computed Essubscriptğ¸ğ‘ E_{s} and Eosubscriptğ¸ğ‘œE_{o} (lineÂ 1), and then adds the link with the largest fractional yğ‘¦y-value to Essubscriptğ¸ğ‘ E_{s} (linesÂ 1â€“1) and the link with the smallest fractional yğ‘¦y-value to Eosubscriptğ¸ğ‘œE_{o} (linesÂ 1â€“1). The iteration repeats until the integer solution rounded according to a given threshold Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is feasible for (27) (lineÂ 1).

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Heuristics based on algebraic connectivity: Another approach is to simplify the objective based on the following observation.

Lemma 3.7.

Minimizing ÏÂ¯Â¯ğœŒ\overline{\rho} in (22) is equivalent to maximizing Î»2â€‹(ğ‘³â€‹(Ea))subscriptğœ†2ğ‘³subscriptğ¸ğ‘\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a})) (the second smallest eigenvalue) if ğœ¶(0)superscriptğœ¶0\bm{\alpha}^{(0)} satisfies

(28) maxiâˆˆVâ€‹âˆ‘j:(i,j)âˆˆE~Î±iâ€‹j(0)+mâ‹…max(i,j)âˆˆE~â¡|Î±iâ€‹j(0)|â‰¤1.subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‰subscript:ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—â‹…ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—1\displaystyle\max_{i\in V}\sum_{j:(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}+m\cdot\max_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}|\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}|\leq 1.

Remark: We can satisfy (28) by making Î±iâ€‹j(0)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}â€™s sufficiently small, e.g., Î±iâ€‹j(0)â‰¡1/(2â€‹mâˆ’1)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—12ğ‘š1\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}\equiv 1/(2m-1), âˆ€(i,j)âˆˆE~for-allğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸\forall(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}.

Under condition (28), we can convert the minimization of ÏÂ¯Â¯ğœŒ\overline{\rho} into a maximization of Î»2â€‹(ğ‘³â€‹(Ea))subscriptğœ†2ğ‘³subscriptğ¸ğ‘\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a})), known as the algebraic connectivity:

(29a) maxğ’šsubscriptğ’š\displaystyle\max_{\bm{y}} Î»2â€‹(âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆE~yiâ€‹jâ€‹ğ‘³iâ€‹j)subscriptğœ†2subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘³ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\quad\lambda_{2}(\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\bm{L}_{ij})
(29b) s.t. (â€‹26â€‹),âˆ€Fâˆˆâ„±^,italic-(26italic-)for-allğ¹^â„±\displaystyle\eqref{eq:independence constraint},~{}~{}\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},
(29c) yiâ€‹jâˆˆ{0,1},âˆ€(i,j)âˆˆE~,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—01for-allğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸\displaystyle y_{ij}\in\{0,1\},~{}~{}\forall(i,j)\in\widetilde{E},

which selects links to maximize the algebraic connectivity under the linear constraints (29b). A similar problem of maximizing the algebraic connectivity of unweighted graphs under cardinality constraint (i.e., âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆE~yiâ€‹jâ‰¤ksubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\leq k) has been studied with some efficient heuristics (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006; He, 2019). Although our problem (29) addresses a weighted graph and more general linear constraints, the existing heuristics can still be adapted for our problem.

Specifically, as Î»2â€‹(âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆE~yiâ€‹jâ€‹ğ‘³iâ€‹j)subscriptğœ†2subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘³ğ‘–ğ‘—\lambda_{2}(\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\bm{L}_{ij}) is a concave function of ğ’šğ’š\bm{y}Â (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006), relaxing the integer constraint (29c) into yiâ€‹jâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—01y_{ij}\in[0,1] turns (29) into a convex optimization that can be solved in polynomial time, based on which we can extract an integer solution via rounding. We can also adapt the greedy perturbation heuristic in (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006) as follows. Let ğ’—â€‹(Ea)ğ’—subscriptğ¸ğ‘\bm{v}(E_{a}) denote the Fiedler vector of ğ‘³â€‹(Ea)ğ‘³subscriptğ¸ğ‘\bm{L}(E_{a}) (i.e., the unit-norm eigenvector corresponding to Î»2â€‹(ğ‘³â€‹(Ea))subscriptğœ†2ğ‘³subscriptğ¸ğ‘\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a}))). It is easy to extend (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006, (10)) into

(30) Î»2â€‹(ğ‘³â€‹(Eaâˆª{(i,j)}))âˆ’Î»2â€‹(ğ‘³â€‹(Ea))â‰¤Î±iâ€‹j(0)â€‹(vâ€‹(Ea)iâˆ’vâ€‹(Ea)j)2.subscriptğœ†2ğ‘³subscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ†2ğ‘³subscriptğ¸ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘£subscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘£subscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ‘—2\displaystyle\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a}\cup\{(i,j)\}))-\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a}))\leq\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}\left(v(E_{a})_{i}-v(E_{a})_{j}\right)^{2}.

Based on this bound, we can apply the greedy heuristic to (29) by repeatedly: (i) computing the Fiedler vector ğ’—â€‹(Ea)ğ’—subscriptğ¸ğ‘\bm{v}(E_{a}) based on the current Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a}, and (ii) augmenting Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a} with the link (i,j)âˆˆE~âˆ–Eağ‘–ğ‘—~ğ¸subscriptğ¸ğ‘(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}\setminus E_{a} that maximizes Î±iâ€‹j(0)â€‹(vâ€‹(Ea)iâˆ’vâ€‹(Ea)j)2subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼0ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘£subscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘£subscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ‘—2\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}\left(v(E_{a})_{i}-v(E_{a})_{j}\right)^{2} subject to (26).

Remark: Even if we can enforce the condition in LemmaÂ 3.7 by suitably setting the initial link weights ğœ¶(0)superscriptğœ¶0\bm{\alpha}^{(0)}, the final link weights are determined by the optimization (16) and thus cannot guarantee the equivalence between ÏÂ¯Â¯ğœŒ\overline{\rho} minimization and algebraic connectivity maximization. As a result, our evaluation shows that Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a}â€™s designed by the above heuristics based on the algebraic connectivity are less effective than those designed based on ÏÂ¯Â¯ğœŒ\overline{\rho} (see SectionÂ 4). However, connecting our problem with algebraic connectivity maximization opens the possibility of leveraging a rich set of existing results, for which the above is just a starting point. In this regard, our contribution is to formally establish this connection and the corresponding condition.

3.4. Overall Solution

Fig.Â 4 illustrates the overall proposed solution as deployed on a centralized orchestrator when initializing DFL tasks, which starts by inferring the necessary information about the underlay using network tomography (Huang and He, 2023), and then selects the links to activate based on predetermined weights ğœ¶(0)superscriptğœ¶0\bm{\alpha}^{(0)} as in SectionÂ 3.3, based on which the link weights are optimized as in SectionÂ 3.2 and the communication schedule is optimized as in SectionÂ 3.1. Our solution is suitable for the centralized deployment as it only uses predetermined information.

The performance of this solution is guaranteed as follows.

Theorem 3.8.

Under the assumption of â„±^âŠ‡â„±â„±^â„±\widehat{\mathcal{F}}\supseteq\mathcal{F} and C^Fâ‰¤CFsubscript^ğ¶ğ¹subscriptğ¶ğ¹\widehat{C}_{F}\leq C_{F} (âˆ€Fâˆˆâ„±for-allğ¹â„±\forall F\in\mathcal{F}), if the proposed solution activates a set of links Eaâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a}^{*}, then D-PSGD under the corresponding design is guaranteed to achieve Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0\epsilon_{0}-convergence as defined in TheoremÂ 3.4 within time Ï„Â¯â€‹(Eaâˆ—)â‹…KÂ¯â€‹(Eaâˆ—)â‹…Â¯ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘Â¯ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘\overline{\tau}(E_{a}^{*})\cdot\overline{K}(E_{a}^{*}) for Ï„Â¯â€‹(â‹…)Â¯ğœâ‹…\overline{\tau}(\cdot) and KÂ¯â€‹(â‹…)Â¯ğ¾â‹…\overline{K}(\cdot) defined in SectionÂ 3.3.1.

Remark: TheoremÂ 3.8 upper-bounds the total training time under our design if network tomography detects all the nonempty categories and does not overestimate the category capacities. According to (Huang and He, 2023), the second assumption holds approximately as the estimation of category capacities is highly accurate, but the first assumption may not hold due to misses in detecting nonempty categories. However, in underlays following symmetric tree-based routing as commonly encountered in edge networks, a new algorithm in (Huang and He, 2024) can detect nearly all the nonempty categories in networks of moderate sizes. We will empirically evaluate the impact of inference errors on the final performance of DFL in SectionÂ 4.

4. Performance Evaluation

We evaluate the proposed algorithms against benchmarks through realistic data-driven simulations in the context of bandwidth-limited wireless edge networks.

4.1. Simulation Setup

4.1.1. Dataset and ML Model

We train a ResNet-50 model with 23,616,394 parameters and a model size of 90.09 MB for image classification on the CIFAR-10 dataset, which consists of 60,000 color images divided into 10 classes. We use 50,000 images for training and the remaining 10,000 images for testing. The dataset undergoes standard preprocessing, including normalization and one-hot encoding of the labels. We set the learning rate to 0.020.020.02 and the mini-batch size to 64 for each agent. These settings are sufficient for D-PSGD to achieve convergence under all evaluated designs. As a sanity check, we also train a 4-layer CNN model based on (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), which has 582,026 parameters and a model size of 2.22 MB, for digit recognition on the MNIST dataset, which comprises 60,000 training images and 10,000 testing images. In both cases, we evenly divide the training data among all the agents after a random shuffle.

4.1.2. Network Topology

We simulate the underlay based on the topologies and link attributes of real wireless edge networks. We consider two important types of networks: (i) WiFi-based wireless mesh networks represented by the RoofnetÂ (Aguayo etÂ al., 2004), which has 33 nodes, 187 links, and a data rate of 1 Mbps, and (ii) millimeter-wave-based Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) networks used to extend the coverage of 5G networksÂ (3GPP, 2018), represented by a hexagon topology with 19 nodes, 56 links, and a data rate of 0.40.40.4 Gbps (Ronkainen etÂ al., 2020). In each topology, we select 101010 low-degree nodes as learning agents (i.e., overlay nodes). We assume the base topology to be a clique among the agents (i.e., any two agents are allowed to communicate), and use the shortest paths (based on hop count) between the agents as the underlay routing paths. The simulated topologies are illustrated in Fig.Â 5.

4.1.3. Benchmarks

We compare the proposed AlgorithmÂ 1 (â€˜SCAâ€™) against the following benchmarks:

  • â€¢

    the baseline of activating all the (overlay) links (â€˜Cliqueâ€™);

  • â€¢

    the ring topology (â€˜Ringâ€™) commonly adopted by industry;

  • â€¢

    the minimum spanning tree computed by Primâ€™s algorithm (â€˜Primâ€™), proposed by (Marfoq etÂ al., 2020) as the state of the art for overlay-based DFL;

  • â€¢

    the simplistic heuristic for (27) based on SDP relaxation plus greedy rounding (â€˜Relaxation-ÏğœŒ\rhoâ€™);

  • â€¢

    the heuristics for (29) based on convex relaxation plus rounding (â€˜Relaxation-Î»ğœ†\lambdaâ€™) or greedy perturbation (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006) (â€˜Greedyâ€™).

We will first evaluate a basic setting where we provide accurate information about the underlay to all the algorithms, use (16) to optimize the link weights under each topology design, and let all the communications occur directly over the underlay routing paths (i.e., without overlay routing). We will separately evaluate the impact of overlay routing, inference errors, and weight design.

4.2. Simulation Results on Roofnet

4.2.1. Results without Overlay Routing

As the most difficult part of our problem is topology design (i.e., optimization of Easubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{a}), we first compare the topology design solutions without overlay routing. As shown in Fig.Â 6, (i) using sparse topologies rather than the clique can effectively reduce the training time without compromising the performance at convergence, (ii) different topology designs only slightly differ in terms of the convergence rate over epochs, but can differ significantly in terms of the convergence rate over the actual (wall-clock) time, and (iii) the proposed design by â€˜SCAâ€™ notably outperforms the others in terms of training time, while achieving the same loss/accuracy at convergence. Note that the time axis is in log scale. A closer examination further shows that the existing topology designs (â€˜Primâ€™, â€˜Ringâ€™) work relatively well in that they not only converge much faster than the baseline (â€˜Cliqueâ€™) but also outperform the other heuristics based on the optimizations we formulate (â€˜Relaxation-ÏğœŒ\rhoâ€™, â€˜Relaxation-Î»ğœ†\lambdaâ€™, â€˜Greedyâ€™). Nevertheless, â€˜SCAâ€™ is able to converge even faster by better approximating the optimal solution to (27). Note that although we have not optimized overlay routing, the proposed algorithm still benefits from the knowledge of how links are shared by routing paths within the underlay (via constraint (26)), which allows it to better balance the convergence rate and the communication time per iteration, while the state-of-the-art design (â€˜Primâ€™) ignores such link sharing. This result highlights the importance of underlay-aware design for overlay-based DFL.

Meanwhile, we note that the simpler heuristics â€˜Relaxation-ÏğœŒ\rhoâ€™ and â€˜Relaxation-Î»ğœ†\lambdaâ€™ outperform â€˜SCAâ€™ in terms of running time, as shown in TableÂ 1, and all the algorithms based on our optimizations are slower than â€˜Primâ€™. This indicates further room for improvement for future work in terms of the tradeoff between the quality of design and the computational efficiency.

4.2.2. Results with Overlay Routing

Fig.Â 7 shows the results after optimizing the communication schedule under each design by the overlay routing optimization (5). Compared with Fig.Â 6 (second row), we see that the training time is further reduced for all the topology designs. However, the improvement is only prominent for the dense topology (â€˜Cliqueâ€™) with a reduction of 28%percent2828\%, while the improvement for the other topologies is incremental (222â€“4%percent44\%). Intuitively, this is because these sparse topologies generate much less load on the underlay network, and hence leave less room for improvement for overlay routing.

4.2.3. Results with Inference Errors

While the above results are obtained under the perfect knowledge of the nonempty categories â„±â„±\mathcal{F} and the category capacities (CF)Fâˆˆâ„±subscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ¹ğ¹â„±(C_{F})_{F\in\mathcal{F}}, the observations therein remain valid under the inferred values of these parameters, as shown in Fig.Â 8, where the inference is performed by the T-COIN algorithm in (Huang and He, 2024) based on packet-level simulations in NS3. Compared with the results under perfect knowledge in Fig.Â 6â€“7, designing the communication demands and schedule based on the inferred information only slightly perturbs the training performance, and the comparison between different designs remains roughly the same.

4.2.4. Results under Other Weight Design

Instead of solving the SDP (16), one could use other designs of link weights. To see the impact of weight design, we have repeated the simulations in Fig.Â 6â€“7 under a common design called Metropolis-Hasting weightsÂ (Xiao etÂ al., 2006). The results in Fig.Â 9 show that the Metropolis-Hasting weights introduce a noticeable delay in convergence compared to our proposed weight design, as evidenced by comparing each curve in Fig.Â 9 with its counterpart in Fig.Â 6â€“7.

4.2.5. Results on MNIST

To check the generalizability of our observations wrt the learning task, we repeat the above tests on MNIST based on the same network topology. The results in Fig.Â 10â€“11 show the following ranking of the algorithms: â€˜SCAâ€™ performs the best, â€˜Cliqueâ€™ performs the worst, and the rest (â€˜Primâ€™, â€˜Ringâ€™, â€˜Relaxation-ÏğœŒ\rhoâ€™, â€˜Greedyâ€™, and â€˜Relaxation-Î»ğœ†\lambdaâ€™) fall in between. The inference errors may change the exact performance of each design, but their comparison remains largely the same. Compared with CIFAR-10, we see that although the small size of MNIST causes the gaps between algorithms to shrink, their comparison remains the same.

4.3. Simulation Results on IAB Network

To further validate our observations in different network scenarios, we repeat the previous tests on the IAB network, as shown in Fig.Â 12â€“15. The results exhibit similar trends as those on Roofnet (Fig.Â 6â€“11), in that the sparse topologies significantly reduce the time in achieving the same level of convergence as the clique, and overlay routing brings more improvement to dense topologies like the clique. Meanwhile, there is also a notable difference: except for the clique, all the topologies perform similarly on the IAB network. Further examination shows that this is because the IAB network is smaller, with fewer hops between the learning agents and less link sharing, and thus leaves less room for improvement. Nevertheless, the proposed algorithm â€˜SCAâ€™ is still among the best-performing solutions. This result demonstrates the generalizability of our previous observations.

4.4. Summary of Results

TablesÂ 2â€“5 summarize the above results in terms of the total wall clock time for DFL to reach convergence, defined as the point at which the variance of accuracy within a sliding window falls below a specified threshold777Specifically, we consider convergence to be achieved when the variance of accuracy within a window of three consecutive epochs remains below 0.0050.0050.005 for at least three consecutive windows.. The results clearly show that (i) using a sparse topology for parameter exchange can significantly reduce the training time compared to using the complete topology, (ii) overlay routing can further improve the training time, although the improvement is much less, and (iii) the state-of-the-art network tomography algorithm (Huang and He, 2024) is accurate enough to support the optimization.

5. Conclusion

We considered, for the first time, communication optimization for running DFL on top of a bandwidth-limited underlay network. To this end, we formulated a framework for jointly optimizing the hyperparameters controlling the communication demands between learning agents and the communication schedule (including routing and flow rates) to fulfill such demands, without cooperation from the underlay. We showed that the resulting problem can be decomposed into a set of interrelated subproblems, and developed efficient algorithms through carefully designed convex relaxations. Our evaluations based on real topologies and datasets validated the efficacy of the proposed solution in significantly reducing the training time without compromising the quality of the trained model. Our results highlight the need of network-application co-design in supporting DFL over bandwidth-limited networks, and our overlay-based approach facilitates the deployment of our solution in existing networks without changing their internal operations.
